questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the marked foramen?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the jugular foramen. The glossopharyngeal nerve passes through it.

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale

  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein

  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery

Foramen magnum

    • Apical ligament and tip of dens

  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.
 

 

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the marked vessel?
questions.solution:
The marked vessel is the basilar artery. The posterior inferior cerebellar artery is not a branch of the basilar artery. It is a branch of the vertebral artery.

Branches of the basilar artery are:

  • Numerous pontine branches
  • Labyrinthine artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior cerebral artery

Note: Labyrinthine artery is usually a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, but variations in its origin include basilar artery, superior cerebellar artery and occasionally posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region. 

Related Pearl: Arteries supplying specific parts of the brain

Parts of Brain Arteries supplying it
Basal ganglia
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior and posterior  choroidal arteries
  • Thalamogeniculate branch of PCA
Internal capsule
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery (Recurrent artery of Heubner) - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior choroidal artery - a branch of ICA
Thalamus
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery
Midbrain
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Pons
  • Basilar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar arteries.
Medulla oblongata
  • Vertebral artery
  • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Cerebellum
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries

 

ACA - Anterior cerebral artery

MCA- Middle cerebral artery

PCA - Posterior cerebral artery

ICA - Internal carotid artery

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the great saphenous vein.

The great saphenous vein starts as the continuation of the medial marginal vein of the foot and ends in the femoral vein by piercing the cribriform fascia.

Tributaries of the great saphenous vein:

Part of the lower limb Tributaries
Ankle Medial marginal veins of the foot
Leg Short saphenous vein and deep veins (via perforators)
Just below the knee

●      Anterior vein of the leg

●      Posterior arch vein

●      Vein from the calf
Thigh

●      Posteromedial vein of the thigh (Accessory saphenous vein)

●      Anterolateral vein of the thigh (Anterior femoral cutaneous vein)
Just before piercing the cribriform fascia (saphenous opening)

●      Superficial epigastric vein

●      Superficial external pudendal vein

●      Superficial circumflex iliac vein
In the saphenous opening Deep external pudendal vein

questions.text: What is the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image of the gluteal region?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the piriformis muscle.

The muscle has its origin from the following structures.

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

It inserts into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibers or above the muscle.

Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position.

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle.

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the structure marked by the black arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the right recurrent laryngeal nerve. It is embryologically derived from the sixth pharyngeal arch

questions.text: What is the level at which the structure marked by the black arrow commonly bifurcates?
questions.solution: The marked structure is the common carotid artery. It usually bifurcates at the level of C3-C4 junction. This corresponds to the upper border of the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text: The following image depicts the dissection of the forearm. Identify structure marked by the red arrow.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the pronator quadratus muscle.

Pronator quadratus is a flat quadrilateral shaped muscle, that extends across the front of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. The muscle is supplied by the anterior interosseus artery and causes the pronation of the forearm.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the muscle marked by the red arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the first lumbrical. It is supplied by the median nerve. The muscle arises from the radial side of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon of the index finger. The muscle is unipennate.

Feature Lumbricals Palmar interossei Dorsal interossei
Number of muscles 4 3 (1st - rudimentary) 4
Nature

1 and 2 - unipennate 

3 and 4 - bipennate

 Unipennate Bipennate
Origin The tendon of flexor digitorum profundus

2nd - ulnar side of the second metacarpal bone

3rd and 4th - from the radial side of 4th and 5th metacarpal bones respectively

 Adjacent sides of bones
Insertion Dorsal digital expansion Dorsal digital expansion Dorsal digital expansion
Nerve supply

1 and 2 - median nerve

3 and 4 - ulnar nerve

 Ulnar nerve Ulnar nerve
Action Flexion at MCP joint Extension of IP joints Adduction  PAD (palmar - adduction) Abduction DAB (dorsal - abduction)

questions.text: What is the root value of the structure marked by the red arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve. Its root value is C5, C6, C7.

The structure can be identified as a musculocutaneous nerve as it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in its course and also supplies the biceps brachii.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts 

Branches
Roots

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
Upper trunk

Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)

Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6).
Lateral cord (LML)

Lateral pectoral nerve (C5-C7)

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)
Medial cord (UM4)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8,T1)

Ulnar nerve (C8,T1)

Medial root of median nerve (C8,T1)
Posterior cord (STARS)

Upper Subscapular nerve (C5,C6)

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6-C8)

Axillary (C5,C6)

Radial (C5-T1)

Lower Subscapular (C5,C6)

 

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the red arrow:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the dissected left cubital fossa and the structure marked is the median nerve.

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression in the anterior aspect of the upper forearm. 

Boundaries:

  • Proximally - epicondylar line
  • Medially - lateral margin of pronator teres
  • Laterally - the medial face of brachioradialis
  • Roof - deep fascia

Contents: (From medial to lateral) - “MBBR”

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery
  • Biceps brachii tendon
  • Radial nerve

questions.text: A professor asks a student to identify the structure marked by the red arrows in the dissected part of the neck. He gives him a hint that this nerve arises from the medulla oblongata. He further adds that its damage causes the structure supplied by it to get deviated to the same side of the lesion. What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked with the red arrows in the image is the hypoglossal nerve. 

The hypoglossal nerve courses lateral to the internal and external carotid artery and the facial artery. The nerve then ascends along the lateral surface of the hyoglossus muscle.

The hypoglossal nerve supplies all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except the palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vago accessory nerve. Deviation of the tongue to the affected side is seen in injury to the hypoglossal nerve.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the highlighted triangle?
questions.solution:
The highlighted triangle is the supraclavicular (subclavian/omoclavicular/ Ho's triangle) triangle. The spinal accessory nerve is not the content of this triangle.

The supraclavicular triangle is the lower and smaller division of the posterior triangle of the neck.

Boundaries :

  • Superior - inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle
  • Inferior - clavicle
  • Anterior - posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Posterior - anterior border of the trapezius

Contents:

  • Nerves - trunks of the brachial plexus, nerve to serratus anterior (long thoracic nerve of bell), suprascapular nerve, nerve to subclavius.
  • Vessels - the third part of the subclavian artery and vein, suprascapular artery and vein, the origin of the transverse cervical artery, lower part of the external jugular vein
  • Lymph nodes

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the marked muscle?

choices.text: It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve
Its action is to adduct the vocal cords
It is attached between the cricoid and arytenoid cartilages
It is active in the production of unvoiced sounds

questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis.

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of the unvoiced sounds.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of insertion of the marked muscle?

choices.text: Lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus
Medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus

questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the pectoralis major. It is attached to the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus.

The pectoralis major has its origin from multiple sites as follows:

  • Sternal half of the clavicle
  • Anterior surface of the sternum
  • First to seventh costal cartilages
  • External oblique aponeurosis

Blood supply:

  • Pectoral branch of the thoracoacromial axis
  • Internal thoracic artery
  • Superior and lateral thoracic artery

Innervation: Medial and lateral pectoral nerves

Action: Adduction and medial rotation of the arm

Other options:

Floor of the intertubercular sulcus  - site of insertion of lattisimus dorsi

Medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus - site of insertion of Teres major

( remembered by “Lady between two majors”, i.e - Lattisimus dorsi between pectoralis major and teres major)

Coracoid process of the scapula - site of insertion of pectoralis minor

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. If the structure marked in red arrow is injured, which of the following clinical manifestations would you expect?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in red is identified to be the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve). Injury to this nerve will result in loss of ankle eversion.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and ankle eversion
  • Diminishes sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved
  • High stepping gait is seen in this nerve injury

The common peroneal nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami. 

It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

The course of the common peroneal nerve is shown below.

Other options:

Plantar flexion is caused by the action of muscles gastrocnemius and soleus innervated by the tibial nerve. 

Ankle inversion is caused by the action of the tibialis posterior muscle innervated by the tibial nerve.

Ankle reflex (S1, S2) is characterised by the plantar flexion of the foot when the calcaneal tendon is struck with a percussion hammer. Thus it is lost in lesions of the tibial nerve.

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the leg and their innervation:

questions.text: Nerve entrapment at the structure marked in the image would result in compression of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is Guyon’s canal. Nerve entrapment here would affect the ulnar nerve.

It can be identified as Guyon’s canal as it is located on the anteromedial side of the flexor aspect of the wrist. Guyon's canal is a 4 cm long canal formed by splitting of the flexor retinaculum along the anteromedial side of the wrist.

Boundaries:

  • Ulnar/Medial - Pisiform bone, flexor carpi ulnaris, and abductor digiti minimi.
  • Lateral - hook of hamate, extrinsic flexor tendons, and the transverse carpal ligaments.
  • Floor - Flexor retinaculum and pisohamate ligaments
  • Roof - Palmar carpal ligament and palmaris brevis

Contents: Ulnar nerve and ulnar artery.

 

Guyon' canal syndrome/handlebar palsy caused by entrapment of the ulnar nerve as it courses through the Guyon’ canal in the wrist is commonly seen in regular cyclists. This occurs due to prolonged pressure over the nerve against the bicycle handlebar. The tunnel of Guyon is clinically significant because it contains the ulnar nerve and artery & is the site of compression injury; the ulnar artery is immediately adjacent and radial to the ulnar nerve.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Posterior tibial nerve

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve 
Notalgia Paresthetica Superficial sensory neuropathy in the infrascapular area (Pruritus + Dysaesthesia)

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the red arrow in the dissected specimen of the dorsum of the hand:
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the extensor pollicis longus tendon. It forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox.

An anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the posterolateral side of the wrist. It is best observed when the thumb is extended. Its boundaries are:

Lateral wall Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)
Medial wall Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
Roof Cephalic vein
Superficial branch of radial nerve
Floor Radial styloid, scaphoid, trapezium, and 1st metacarpal
Content Radial artery

 

The image below shows the tendons seen on the dissection of the dorsum of the hand.

questions.text: The image shows the dorsum of the hand. What is the action of the marked structure on the fingers?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the dorsal interossei of the hand. Their action is abduction of the fingers.

Dorsal interossei are bipennate muscles originating from the adjacent metacarpal bone. They attach to the middle three fingers on both sides and do not attach to the thumb and little finger. 

Muscle Dorsal Interossei
Origin Contiguous sides of shafts of metacarpal bones
Insertion Proximal phalanges of index, middle, and ring fingers and dorsal extensor expansion
Nerve supply Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Nerve roots C8; T1
Action  

Dorsal interossei abduct fingers from the center of the third finger, flex metacarpophalangeal joints and extend interphalangeal joints

 

 

Dorsal digital expansion or Extensor expansion is a small triangular aponeurosis covering the dorsum of the proximal phalanx formed by the expansion of the tendons of the extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus. The muscles joining the expansion are extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

 Nerve

 1.Book test

 3.Froment's sign

 2. Abductor   pollicis brevis

 3. Flexor   digitorum   profundus+   Flexor pollicis   longus (Ant.   interosseous   nerve)

 4.Flexor   Digitorum   superficialis+   Lateral half of   Flexor   digitorum   profundus
 Radial   nerve

 1.Thumb and   finger drop

 2. Wrist drop

 1.Extensors(Post.   interosseous   nerve)

 2.Extensors of   wrist.

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternoclediomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: The following image shows the axilla. What is the structure marked in red arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is lateral to the third part of the axillary artery. Hence, it is identified as the trunk of the Median nerve.

Relations of the third part of the axillary artery: 

Anterior: Skin and fascia, the medial root of the median nerve

Posterior: Lower part of subscapularis and tendons of lattisimus dorsi and teres major, radial and axillary nerves

Lateral: Musculocutaneous nerve (for a short distance), Lateral root, and then the trunk of the median nerve

Medial: Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm, Ulnar nerve

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in red arrow:
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein.

The superior mesenteric artery originates from the abdominal aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra.

Its branches include:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note: Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: What is the distance of the marked area from the pylorus of the stomach?
questions.solution:
The marked area corresponds to the opening of the pancreatic and the common bile duct in the second part of the duodenum. This is about 8 to 10 cm from the pylorus of the stomach.

The pancreatic duct and the common bile duct join together to form a common channel. This opens into a mucosal elevation in the posteromedial wall of the second part of the duodenum called the major duodenal papilla. This is about 8 to 10 cm from the pylorus of the stomach.

At times, an accessory pancreatic duct is present which opens into the minor duodenal papilla about 6 to 8cm from the pylorus of the stomach.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked red.
questions.solution:
The marked area can be identified as the renal papilla, as it forms the conical apex of a renal pyramid.

The renal papillae open into the minor calyces.

The papilla is the conical apex of a renal pyramid, where the urine from the collecting ducts enter into the minor calyces. The minor calyces unite to form the major calyces, which eventually results in forming a renal pelvis.

questions.text: What is the correct arrangement of the structures in the marked area from anterior to posterior?

choices.text: Renal artery, Renal vein, Renal pelvis
Renal vein, Renal artery, Renal pelvis
Renal pelvis, Renal artery, Renal vein
Renal pelvis, Renal vein, Renal artery

questions.solution:
The hilum of the kidney contains the following structures from anterior to posterior:

  • Renal vein
  • Renal artery
  • Renal pelvis

questions.text: What does the marked yellow line represent?
questions.solution:
The marked yellow line represents the main portal fissure - Cantlie’s line. The main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver, It contains the middle hepatic vein.

Umbilical fissure - It separates the segment 3 from segment 4, within the left medial sector. It is marked by the attachment of the falciform ligament.

Venous fissure - It is a direct continuation of the umbilical fissure on the undersurface of the liver. It contains the ligamentum venosum (obliterated ductus venosus).

Fissure of Ganz - It lies on the undersurface of the right lobe of the liver behind the gallbladder fossa. It is also called Rouviere’s sulcus. It marks the division of the portal pedicle to the right posterior sector.

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the marked structure in the retroperitoneum?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the uncinate process of the pancreas. It is embryologically derived from the ventral pancreatic bud.

Embryology of pancreas:  The pancreas develops from two buds, dorsal, and ventral, originating from the endodermal lining of the duodenum. When the duodenum rotates and becomes C-shaped, the ventral bud gets positioned immediately below and behind the dorsal bud. This is followed by the fusion of the parenchyma and the duct systems of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds.

Parenchyma of the pancreas:

  • Ventral pancreatic bud forms the lower part of the head and uncinate process
  • Dorsal pancreatic bud forms the upper part of the head, neck, body, and tail

Pancreatic ducts:

  • Main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) is formed by the duct of ventral bud (proximal part),  oblique cross-communication between the 2 ducts (middle part), and the duct of dorsal bud (distal part).
  • Accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini) is formed by the proximal part of the dorsal pancreatic duct.

questions.text: What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the anterior interventricular artery.

The anterior interventricular artery is a branch of the left coronary artery.

The left coronary artery arises from the left aortic sinus (left posterior sinus ) of the ascending aorta. It passes between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then runs in the coronary sulcus. It divides into its two terminal branches in the coronary sulcus. They are:

  • Anterior interventricular branch - also called the left anterior descending artery (LAD)

Their branches include - Left conal artery, anterior ventricular branches, anterior septal perforating branches, left diagonal artery

  • Circumflex branch - It gives a left marginal artery also called the obtuse marginal artery supplying the left ventricle.

questions.text: What is the Couinaud liver segment pointed to in the image?
questions.solution:
The Couinaud segment pointed in the cadaveric specimen is IV (4).

The segment IV lies between the umbilical fissure and the main portal fissure. The quadrate lobe is within this segment.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: Which of the following nerves give rise to the structures marked with red arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked structures are the supratrochlear and supraorbital nerves. They are the branches of the frontal nerve.

The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve gives three main branches in the orbit - lacrimal, frontal, and nasociliary nerves. These branches enter the orbit through the superior orbital fissure.

Lacrimal nerve: It supplies  the lacrimal gland, conjunctiva and skin covering the lateral part of the upper eyelid.

Frontal nerve: It is the largest branch of the ophthalmic nerve. This nerve divides into a medial supratrochlear nerve and lateral supraorbital nerve. These nerves end up supplying the conjunctiva and skin of the upper eyelid and forehead.

Nasociliary nerve: Their branches include:

  • Anterior ethmoidal nerve
  • Posterior ethmoidal nerve
  • Infratrochlear nerve
  • Long ciliary nerves
  • Ramus communicans to the ciliary ganglion

questions.text: What is the structure marked with a red arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
It is identified as the subclavian artery because it is seen to emerge into the supraclavicular fossa behind the scalenus anterior muscle.

Other points of identification:

  • The phrenic nerve is separated from the subclavian artery by the scalenus anterior muscle.
  • The upper and middle trunks of the brachial plexus are superior to the subclavian artery
  • The scalenus medius is seen behind the subclavian artery

Subclavian arteries:

The right subclavian artery is a branch of the brachiocephalic trunk whereas the left one is a direct branch of the arch of the aorta.

The subclavian artery extends from the site of origin to the outer border of the first rib. In this extent, the artery is divided into three parts by the scalenus anterior muscle. Beyond the outer border of the first rib, it continues as the axillary artery.

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the sphenoid sinus. It drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the red arrow:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the Masseter muscle.

It can be identified as masseter, as the parotid duct with the gland and the branches of the facial nerve lies superficial to the muscle.

The muscle originates in three layers from the zygomatic bone and inserted to the ramus of the mandible. It is innervated by the mandibular nerve. Its action is to elevate the mandible resulting in occlusion of the teeth, thereby aiding the mastication.

questions.text: Which of the following would be a clinical manifestation due to the injury to the structure marked by the red arrow?

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the anterior two third of the tongue
Loss of sensation of the posterior one third of the tongue
Deviation of the tongue to the affected side
Deviation of the tongue to the healthy side

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the lingual nerve. Injury to the lingual nerve results in loss of sensation to the anterior two thirds of the tongue.

Points of identification: The nerve runs downwards and forwards on the surface of the medial pterygoid muscle.

The lingual nerve arises from the posterior trunk of the mandibular nerve. It is joined by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve and a branch from the inferior alveolar nerve.

Loss of sensation of the posterior one third of the tongue is due to the injury to glossopharyngeal nerve.

Deviation of the tongue to the affected side is seen in injury to the hypoglossal nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Anterior 2/3rds

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: During a routine dissection class, your professor asks you to identify the structures seen in the given specimen. Correctly match the following with their respective structures:

choices.text: 1- Putamen; 2- Globus pallidus; 3- Caudate nucleus; 4- Thalamus
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- Thalamus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Thalamus; 2- Caudate nucleus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- putamen; 3- Thalamus; 4- Globus pallidus

questions.solution:
The correct match is: 1- Caudate nucleus, 2- Thalamus, 3- Globus pallidus, 4- Putamen. The given image shows the coronal section of the brain with different parts of the basal ganglia.

The basal ganglia constitutes accessory motor system that functions in close association with the cerebral cortex and corticospinal motor control system. On each side of the brain, these ganglia consist of the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen 

The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Both the Putamen and external capsule lie lateral to globus pallidus. It receives fibers from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in parkinsonism disease.

Related Pearl: Connections and Neurotransmitters in Basal Ganglia

  Input Output Neurotransmitter
Corpus Striatum Cerebral cortex and Thalamus GPe and GPi

95% GABA (small neurons)

5% Ach (large neurons) / Somatostatin (Medium neurons)
GPe Striatum GPi and Subthalamic nucleus GABA 
GPi and Substantia nigra pars reticulate (SNpR) Striatum and GPe Ventrolateral and ventroanterior Thalamus GABA
Subthalamic nucleus GPe GPi and GPe Glutamate
Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNpC) Striatum Striatum Dopamine
Ventrolateral Thalamus GPi and SNpR Premotor Cortex Glutamate

Related Pearl: Abnormal movements

 

 Movement Site Description Cause
Intentional tremor Cerebellum Only on activity 
  • Trauma
  • Stroke
  • Alcohol
  • Drugs
Resting tremor

Substantia nigra

Red nucleus

 Disappear on movement
  •  Parkinsonism
Hyperkinetic tremor Sympathetic overactivity  Precipitated by emotion , stress
  • Anxiety 
  • Hyperthyroidism 
Asterixis Cortex Inability to sustain a muscle contraction while performing a complex motor movement
  • Hepatic encephalopathy 
Chorea Caudate nucleus and putamen  Rapid jerky movement
  • Rheumatic chorea
  • Huntington chorea
  • Drug induced 
Hemibalismus Subthalamic nucleus Unilateral wild flinging violent movement of large proximal joints
  • Vascular>degenerative 
Athetosis Basal ganglia- Globus Pallidum Slow writhing movement involving distal joints
  • Vascular 
  • Degenerative 
  • Infiltrative

questions.text: Identify the area marked with a red arrow.
questions.solution:
The area marked in the red arrow is the hypoglossal trigone.

The above image represents the floor of the fourth ventricle. It is a shallow diamond-shaped depression on the dorsal surfaces of the pons and the rostral half of the medulla. It contains the nuclei of the cranial nerves (V-XII).

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullaris
  • Striae medullaris divides the rhomboid fossa into 2parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary

Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:

  • Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus
  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)

Upper and lower ends of sulcus:

  • The bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus
  • Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea
  • Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea

Cranial nerve nucleus elevations:

  • Elevation on the medial eminence: Facial colliculus
  • Elevations in the lowermost area in the shape of 2 triangles: Hypoglossal and vagal triangles

Circumventricular organ:

  • Between the vagal triangle and gracile tubercle below: Area postrema

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked area is pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion and side to side movement of the jaw.

In addition, lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted to the articular disc and capsule of TMJ.

Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It inserted into the lateral surface of ramus of the mandible and coronoid process

Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and articular disc.

 Medial pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Deep head arises from medial surface of lateral pterygoid plate and pyramidal process of palatine bone. Superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
  • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of mandible

questions.text: All of the following supply the marked structure except :
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the right ventricle. It is not supplied by the diagonal artery.

The diagonal artery is a branch of the anterior interventricular artery supplying the left ventricle. This is present in about 30-50% of the population.

The right ventricle is mostly supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches such as the marginal artery.

The anterior interventricular artery gives off 1-2 anterior right ventricular branches.

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is fornix which is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

The anteromedial central branches from the anterior cerebral artery supply the fornix along with optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, hypothalamus, para-olfactory areas, and cingulate gyrus.

questions.text: The given image is the cross-section of the midbrain. A lesion in the area marked with red color will lead to

choices.text: Ipsilateral paralysis of the lower part of the face
Contralateral paralysis of the whole face

questions.solution:
The above image shows the area of midbrain damaged in Weber syndrome. In Weber syndrome, there is involvement of oculomotor nerve leading to ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia.

Weber syndrome:

It is caused by the occlusion of a branch of the posterior cerebral artery that supplies the midbrain, resulting in the necrosis of brain tissue involving the oculomotor nerve and crus cerebri (involving frontopontine, corticospinal and corticonuclear fibers).

There is ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia and contralateral paralysis of the lower part of the face, the tongue, and the arm and leg.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the ulnar artery, seen contributing to the superficial palmar arch.

It passes deep to the Guyon's canal in the wrist and contributes to the superficial and deep palmar arch.

questions.text: The following image shows the superior view of the first cervical vertebra. The part of the bone marked as number 7 gives attachment to ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Atlas bone. The part marked as number 7 is the posterior arch, and its inferior border gives attachment to ligamentum flavum.

 

Atlas (C1): Bony features include no body and spinous processes. It has 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets, anterior and posterior arches, and 2 transverse processes with lateral transverse foramen through which the vertebral vessels pass.

The anterior arch provides attachment to the anterior longitudinal ligament anteriorly and articulates with the facet of dens posteriorly.

The superior border of the posterior arch is attached to the atlantooccipital membrane and its inferior border is attached to the ligamentum flavum.

Articulation of the atlas:

  • The atlantooccipital joint allows the head to nod up and down (like showing yes).
  • The atlantoaxial joint allows the head to turn side to side (like showing no).

Axis (C2): Bony features include a cylindrical body, transverse process with transverse foramen, and a bifid spine. The dens (odontoid process) projects up to the space left due to the missing body of C1.

The given image shows the articulation of the atlas and the axis:

 

The stability of the vertebral column is maintained mainly by 4 ligaments - the anterior longitudinal, posterior longitudinal, ligamentum flavum, and the interspinous ligament.

C1 compression fracture at multiple sites is called Jefferson fracture. C2 hyperextension fracture is also called hangman fracture.

questions.text: Structure marked “?” in below given image is
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the third ventricle and structure marked “?” is mamillary body.

The mammillary bodies are pea-sized eminences anterior to the posterior perforated substance.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is ansa cervicalis and thyrohyoid is not supplied by it. Thyrohyoid is supplied by the C1 fibers through the hypoglossal nerve.

The muscles supplied by ansa cervicalis are:

  • Sternothyroid
  • Sternohyoid
  • Omohyoid both inferior and superior belly

The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop embedded in the anterior wall of the carotid sheath. It is formed by two roots:

  • The superior root is a continuation of the descending branch of the hypoglossal nerve. It is derived from the 1st cervical nerve (C1) and supplies the superior belly of the omohyoid.
  • The inferior root is derived from the 2nd and 3rd cervical spinal nerves (C2, C3).

questions.text: Which of the following structure passes through the foramen marked?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is foramen ovale and mandibular nerve passes through it.

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)

  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

Foramen ovale

    • Apical ligament and tip of dens

    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: True regarding the lesion of the structure marked by the arrow  is:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the radial nerve demonstrated in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the radial nerve leads to a wrist drop.

Ape thumb deformity is seen in a lesion of the median nerve.

Claw hand deformity is seen in a lesion of the ulnar nerve. 

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

questions.text: Identify the muscle marked as A in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The muscle labeled as A is anconeus and its functions are

  • Abduction of the wrist in pronated position
  • Accessory extension of elbow joint

Other options: 

  • The muscle marked as B is extensor carpi radialis brevis, and it extends and abducts the wrist joint
  • The muscle marked as C is extensor digitorum, and it mainly extends the index, middle, ring, and little fingers and also extends the wrist.
  • The muscle marked as D is extensor carpi ulnaris, and it extends and adducts the wrist joint.

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image shows the Trochlear nerve. It is identified easily as it is the only cranial nerve to emerge from the dorsal surface of the brainstem.

Trochlear nerve:

  • Thinnest/smallest cranial nerve
  • Only cranial nerve with Dorsal exit
  • emerges from the midbrain and passes onto the crus of the cerebral peduncle on its lateral surface.
  • Longest intracranial course
  • Only nerve with internal decussation
  • Innervates superior oblique muscle

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is incus.

This is an image taken during mastoidectomy. The incus articulates with the malleus and has a short process and a long process. The long process articulates with the head of the stapes.

CT: chorda tympani; I: incus; JB: jugular bulb; LSC: lateral semicirular canal; M: malleus; PSC: posterior semicircular canal; S: stapes; SM: stapedius muscle; SSC: superior semicircular canal; VIIms: mastoid segment of VII cranial nerve; VIIts: tympanic segment of VII cranial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the oculomotor nerve and it does not supply the superior oblique muscle. Superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve.

 All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

questions.text: Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The artery marked is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This artery branches out from the vertebral artery and it is the largest branch of the vertebral artery.

The following image shows the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below causes?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the pyramid containing the pyramidal tracts. A lesion here leads to contralateral hemiplegia.

Related Pearl: Effects of Various Lesions and Brainstem Transections

Label

Level of transection

Vagi intact

Vagi cut

A

Complete transection above pons

Regular breathing continues

Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

B

Mid-pontine level section

Regular breathing continues

Apneusis develops

C

Transection midway between pons and medulla

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below medulla

Spontaneous respiration ceases

Spontaneous respiration ceases

CP - middle cerebellar peduncle

DRG - Dorsal group of respiratory neurons

IC - inferior colliculus

NPBL - nucleus parabrachialis (pneumotaxic center)

VRG - ventral group of respiratory neurons

4th vent - fourth ventricle.
